And thus when they appear from the limb, then cover that part with a plum of lead whose weight is equal to two drams. Enter into the limb to the amount of two drams, and notice that and leave the lead suspended from the limb
E tantas veguadas cum yeys de lu alcuna causa a las partidas defora, envolveys aquo em plom e noza aquel.	And as often as you see that there is a cause to the parts outside, cover with lead and notice that
E si mot es prolonguat, lahoras tu inscideys una partida de lu e envolopa le romanent; e no inscidas aquela de razit entro que sia fora yssida, quar si inscideys aquela es contrayta e intra en la carn e fa accidir apostema e poyredura en le loc e ulceracio mala.	And if it is not prolonged, then immediately cut off a part of the limb and cover what remains; do not cut off that which is contracted inwards, for if you cut that which is contracted inwards it will cause pus to accumulate in the flesh and ulcerate badly
Per que cove que sia tractada suaument e sia extrayta petit a petit, entro que sia fora-gitada del derier de lu e no remangua de lu alcuna causa en le cors.	For it must be treated gently and slowly extracted little by little, until it is expelled from behind the limb and no remains of it is left in the body
E de aquesta vena es yssit en alcus homes que es en la sua longitut de v palms e de detz e ja es pervengut a mi que yssic un de xx palms.	And from this vein is extracted in a cubit which is in its length of five palms and twelve fingers, and already I have known that it has been extracted from a cubit and a half of palms
E si es inscidida en la hora de la sua medicacio, lahoras intromet lo ray en le trauc de lu e perfora aquela am lonc trauc am le cors, entro que sia evacuat tot aquo que es en la materia, e administra putrefaccio del loc per alcus dias am medicinas; e aprop cura aquela per la curacio de apostemas.	And if it is cut at the time of its treatment, then enter the ray in the thigh of the limb and perforate that along the thigh to the bone, until all that is in the matter is evacuated, and administer putrefying of the limb for several days with medicines; and at the same time care for the cure of the abscesses.
E aquesta vena alcunas veguadas ha motz ramps, e majorment quan apar a la junctura del pe o en le pe, e veno a lu motz orrificis, e es yssit de quascu orrifici ram.	And this vein has often been seen to be more swollen when it appears at the ankle or in the foot, and it gives rise to numerous ulcers, and is said to be the cause of many ulcers of the limb.
E donc cura aquela ayssi cum havem dit en la divisio e am aquo que es desus dit.	And therefore care for it as we have said in the division and as is said above
De sectione super vermes generatos sub cute et dicitur aegritudo bovina.	From a section above worms generated under the cuticle and is called bovine gout.
Aquesta malautia es nompnada en alcuna terra deves nos malautia bovina per so quar motas veguadas endeve als bious e es verm pauc un le qual es nat entre la codena e la carn, e va en tot le cos pujan e devalan, e es mostrat al sentiment deves le sieu anament de membre en membre entro que disromp la codena e yeys fora.	This disease is called in every land bovine gout because it is seen in cows and is very rare among men. It goes through all the joints and bones, and is shown by the feeling of swelling of the limb until it breaks the bone and comes out.
E la generacio de lu es per putrefaccio de alcunas humors ayssi cum accideysso verms e serpentz e lombrics e ascaridas en le ventre.	And the generation of it is from the putrefaction of some humors as well as from worms and serpents and worms and lice in the belly
E es temut per la malicia de lu, quar quan el va en le cors e es elevat al cap, e es pervengut al huel, lahoras fort leu uebre en lu e intra e destruzeys le huel, e aquo endeve motas veguadas.	It is feared for the malice of it, for when it enters the body and is raised to the head, it reaches the brain, and there it causes great damage, and that is what causes the swelling of the limb
E donc quan tu voles curar aquel e extraire lu, lahoras no se fa si no deves la sieua ambulacio e apparacio de lu al sentiment, e adonc cove que tu strenhas aquo que es sobre lu e aquo que es dejos lu am liament e constriccio fort, e aprop secca sobre lu e extratz aquel.	And therefore when you want to cure it and extract it, it must not be done without causing the limb to walk and appear to the feeling, and when you have done that cover what is above it and what is left of it with the ligament and strong constriction, and at the same time dry it up and extract it
E si es preondat en la carn e no le atrobes, lahoras tu pausa cauteri am foc sobre le loc entro que mora, e la major causa que es temuda es corrupcio de lu am la qual corrump le loc ayssi cum havem dit.	And if it is prolonged in the bone and you do not touch it, then immediately put a cautery on the surface of the limb until it remains still, and the greatest cause that is feared is the corruption of it as we have said above
May si tu vezes aquel esser pervengut al cap prop del huel, lahoras strenh sobre le sobrecil am fort strictura, e aprop secsa sobre lu, e extratz aquel; e cove que·l malaute use de mondificacio del sieu cors am medicinas evacuantz humors putridas malas, e guarda se de viandas generantz putrefaccio.	May sometimes when it comes near the head near the brain, then strengthen over the bone with strong constriction, and at the same time dry up over it, and extract it; and cover that the disease uses as a remedy of the evacuation of bad humors, and keep away from foods that generate putrefaction
De sectione super aegritudinem nafir.	From a section above the gout.
Aquesta malautia es nompnada en nostra terra nafir, e es dolor la qual ve en alcus membres, e aprop es permudada de membre en membre.	This disease is called in our land nafir, and it is a pain that is seen in several limbs, and it is usually transferred from limb to limb
E yeu ja e vista aquela segon que yeu te recomtare.	And I have already seen that as I will tell you
Yeu fu apelat a una femna malauta ad una vila, e descubric le sieu bras e vi una imflacio petita en la vena funis del bras, e pus que fu romas per una hora, vi aquela imflacio anar ayssi cum va verm pujan ad aquest, mays pus leugierament que esser por, ayssi cum si fos argent viu quan corr de loc en loc.	I was called to a sick woman in a village, and I saw her arms swell up and noticed a small swelling in the funis vein of the arm, and when I had stayed for an hour, I saw that swelling disappear just as quickly as it had appeared, as if it had been gold that was moving from place to place
E adonc anet s’en la dolor de aquel loc e fiquet se en le muscle, e aprop aqui stec per una hora.	And then I felt pain in that limb and it became stiff in the muscle, and I stayed there for an hour
E aprop correc en l’autre cors entro que pervenc al autre bras.	And then I went to the other limb until I reached the other arm
E aprop recomtec a mi que revolvia se per tot le cors sieu segon que yeu vi; e fo trop meravelat de la permutacio de lu e de la velocitat de membre en membre.	And I told her that I saw that she was rotating all over her body as I had seen; and I was amazed at the transformation of her limbs and the speed from limb to limb
E yeu ja havia vist denant aquo en les mieus huels segon aquela manieyra, empero yeu he vistz motz les quals atroban dolor esser permutada de membra a membre.	And indeed I have seen on many occasions previously that these same humors cause pain that travels from limb to limb.
Mays no vi aquo am les huels ayssi cum en la femna.	I have never seen anything like that in the thighs before.</end_of_turn>
E yeu no cogiti esser aquo sino que es per aquo quar la femna era de viela, on so de secs cors e de venas descubertas, e en aquesta apparec al sentiment aquela ventositat permutada.	And I do not think that is anything other than that the thigh was old, with dry bones and exposed veins, and that is why it feels that way.</end_of_turn>
E es necessari que no apparesca segon aquesta retro-curacio en aquels que son delicioses e am cors humitz de venas ameguadas.	And it is necessary that it does not appear like this backward curvature in those who are delicate and have humors full of veins hidden beneath the skin.</end_of_turn
E cum tu voles la curacio de lu, e le pacient sent aquela dolor, lahoras no es a tu aparent al huel ayssi cum havem dit, lahoras tu strenh sobre aquel e dejos lu leugierament e secse sobre aquel entro que sia yssida aquela ventositat coartada, e cauterize le loc.	And when you wish to cure them, and the patient feels that pain, do not think that it is your responsibility just because we have said so, but strengthen your hand over that area and leave it slightly tense until the swelling has subsided, and cauterize the area.</end_of_turn
Mays si tu no la vezes am los tieus huels, alhoras tu cura aquel am excussio del cors e am aquo que expelleys ventositatz, e carmina aquelas am pillulas fetidas e am pillulas de serapi e semblantz.	If you do not see the thighs again, at least you have cured the swelling of the limb and expelled the wind, and sing those who are yellow and those who are black bile.</end_of_turn>
De extraccio de sagetas.	From the extraction of arrows.</end_of_turn
Sagetas son diversificadas segon las specias, e segon les locs dels cors en les quals cazo, quar la lor diversitat es que de aquellas so que han grans puntas, e petitas, e concavas, e sordas, so es solidas; e de lor so que han tres angles, e de aquelas a las quals so que han lenguas; e de aquelas a las quals so astelas.	Arrows are diverse according to their species and the locations of the body in which they are cast, because their diversity is that some have large heads and small bodies, while others have concave or rounded heads, so they are solid; and some have three angles, and others have tongues; and still others have bars.</end_of_turn
E aquela que es segon les membres e las pessas en las quals cazo es segon dos manieyras: quar les membres o so membres principals concaus, ayssi cum le cervel, le cor, e·l fitge, e le pulmo, e les ronhos, e les budels, e la vezica, e a lor semblantz; e donc quan catz en alcu de aquestz membres e aparo a tu senhals de mort, la qual causa yeu recomtare aprop, lahoras cove que tu evites extraccio de aquela sageta en aquels quar la mort siec aquel en le qual en las majors disposicios, e quan a tu no appareysso aquestz mals senhals, e la sageta no es amaguada en la profunditat del membre, lahoras tu extratz aquela e cura la plagua.	And that which is according to the limbs and the parts in which it is cast is according to two methods: because the principal limbs such as the head, the heart, the liver, the lungs, the intestines, the bladder, and the testicles are causants; and therefore when you hit any of these limbs and see signs of death in them, which I recommend you to avoid, the cause is that the arrow has penetrated too deeply into the limb, and when you do not see these signs and the arrow is not buried too deeply in the limb, then you must extract it and cure the wound.</end_of_turn
E dels senhals del servel es quan catz en lu sageta, e trespassa le os, e es yssit del cyphac le qual es sobre le cervel, quar accideys per lu soda vehement, e scotomia, e vertige, e rogor en les huels, e imflamacio e rogor de la lengua, e spasme e permixtio de entendament e vomi de colera, e fort leu es abscindida la paraula e es destruida la votz, e es yssit del loc de la plagua humiditat blanca semblant a pols, e yeys de lu semblant ad aquositat de la carn.	And as for the signs of the servant when he has been hit by the arrow and has passed out, it is when the head swells with great swelling, causing vomiting, dizziness, and vertigo, swelling and vomiting of the tongue, spasm and loss of understanding, and vomiting of bile, and great swelling of the belly like a white substance resembling pus, and yellowing of the urine resembling the color of urine.</end_of_turn
E donc si appareyso a tu aquestz senhals, lahoras tu abste de la curacio e de la extraccio de la sageta, si non es fora.	And therefore if you see these signs, do not attempt to cure or extract the arrow, if not outside.</end_of_turn
Mays les senhals de la sageta quan catz en le cor, so que ela es prop de la mamila senestra, e sent am aquela quays sia ficada en causa dura, e no es causa vueda; e fort leu le movement de la sageta es semblant a movement del pols, e corr de la plagua sanc negra, e siec aquel fregiditat de las extremitatz, e suzor freja, e sincopi; e donc sapias que la mort descen ses tot dopte.	More often than not when the arrow hits the heart, it is because of the left nipple, and it is fixed with great force, and is not a casual accident; and when the movement of the arrow is like that of a fist, and it is black like the plague, and if there is any coldness in the limbs, sweating, fainting, and loss of breath; and therefore you must know that death approaches immediately.</end_of_turn
E les senhals quan la sageta ha plaglat le pulmo so eyssiment de sanc spumos de la plagua, e les vayssels que so prop del col so apostematz, e es mudada la color del malaute, e expira sperit gran aut, e demanda atraccio de ayre freg.	And the signs when the arrow has struck the lung are as follows: immediate expectoration of black clots of the plague, swelling of the blood vessels that are near the belly, change in the color of the vomit, great expiration of air, and a request for air that is cold to the touch.</end_of_turn
E si catz la sageta en le velament le qual es en le pietz, e la dolor lahoras es prop de las costas petitas, e es fayt le ale gran am vehement dolor e am sospir, e no so maugutz totz les membres dels muscles.	And if the arrow hits the small intestines, the pain is caused by the lower ribs, and it is characterized by great swelling of the abdomen and great pain and difficulty breathing, and the muscles are stiff throughout.</end_of_turn
E si catz la sageta en le stomac, lahoras fort leu yeys de la plagua vianda alcuna indigesta.	And if the arrow hits the stomach, then vomiting of the plague comes immediately with any food indigestible.</end_of_turn
E si catz la sageta en le ventre, e es ficada en lu, yeys alcuna fenda de la plagua, o la tela, o budel le qual es disromput, e no es speransa en la curacio de lu extraccio de la sageta.	And if the arrow hits the belly and remains there, there is immediate opening of the flesh, or of the membrane or intestine which is broken, and no hope remains for the cure of the extraction of the arrow.</end_of_turn
E si la sageta catz en la vesica, e es yssida defora urina, e procesesca de lu alcuna causa a las partidas defora, e fort leu es dolor sobre le malaute, lahoras sapias que es mortal.	And if the arrow hits the bladder and comes out, and there is blood in the urine, and it goes away from the cause of the wound, and there is great pain over the abdomen, then you must know that it is deadly.</end_of_turn
Mays les autres membres ayssi cum es la cara, le col, e·l golayro, e las spallas e le adjutori, e les spondils del dos, e la furcula, e la coysa, e la camba e a lor semblantz dels membres, son salvatz segon las majors disposicios quan la sageta no atroba vena ni arteria e no es sageta venenosa.	And as for the rest of the body, such as the face, the neck, the throat, the armpits, the flanks, the chest, and the limbs, they are saved as far as possible when the arrow does not pierce any vein or artery and is not venomous.</end_of_turn
E yeu recomtare aquo a tu que he vist del esser de aquestas sagetas, per que signifiques per aquo sobre la curacio tieua.	I recommend to you what I have seen about the being of these arrows, because it signifies for you the treatment of your ailment.</end_of_turn>
La qual causa es, quar en un home cazec sageta en le lacrimal del huel de lu en la razitz del nas, e yeu extrayssi aquela a lu del autra partida, dejos le grays de l’aurelha de lu, e es sanat, e no accidic en le huel de lu nocument.	The cause is that in a healthy man a sharp arrow has pierced the tear duct of his eye at the root of his nose, and I have extracted that from the other side, leaving the pupil of his eye gray, and he is cured, and no inflammation has occurred in his eye since.
E extrayssi autra sageta a un Juzeu la qual cazec en lu en lo grays del sieu huel, dejos la palpebra pus dejos, e la sageta ja era occultada e no so conseguit de aquela sino una petita extremitat am la qual adhereys al sieu fust, e era gran sageta de las sagetas agudas dels Turcs , am ferr leon en la qual no havia aurelhas.	And I extracted another arrow from a boy who had pierced his eye with it in the gray of his eyebrow, I left the eyelid closed, and the arrow was already hidden, and I did not manage to extract it from him except for a small piece which adhered to his eyebrow, and it was a great arrow among the sharp arrows of the Turks, with gold in which there were no pupils.</end_of_turn>
E senat es le Juzieu , e no accidic en le sieu huel mal accident.	And thus is the boy, and no inflammation has occurred in his eye since.</end_of_turn>
E extrayssi una autra sageta a un home Crestia la qual era cazuta en le golayro, e era sageta arabica, e es aquela a la qual so aurelhas; e adonc yeu inscidegui sobre aquela entre doas guidegi, e ja era submersa en le golayro de lu; e adonc yeu so subtiliat am aquela, e aprop extraxi aquela, e es sanat le Crestia .	And I extracted another arrow from a Christian who had been pierced in the groin, and it was an Arabian arrow, and those are the ones for which there are pupils; and when I saw that it had plunged into two ribs, and it was already submerged in his groin; then I cautiously pulled it out with that, and thus the Christian was cured.</end_of_turn>
E extraxi autra sageta a un home la qual era cazuta en le sieu ventre, e cogitegui que moris per aquela; e donc, pus que foro passatz xxx dias e no es mudat sobre lu alcuna causa de las suas disposicios, inscidegui sobre la sageta e engenagui sobre aquela, e es sanat, e no accidic a lu accident mal.	And I extracted another arrow from a man who had been pierced in the belly, and I thought that he would die from it; and therefore, when more than thirty days had passed and there had been no change in his condition, I saw the arrow and pulled it out, and he was cured, and no inflammation occurred to him.</end_of_turn
E vi mays un home en le qual cazec una sageta en le dos de lu, e consolidada es la plagua sobre lu, e pus que foc aprop set ans, yssic la sageta en la razitz de la coyssa.	And I saw a man in whom an arrow had pierced both eyes, and consolidation had settled over them; and when I approached and saw that the arrow had gone into the root of the eyebrow, I extracted it.</end_of_turn>
E vi una femna a la qual cazec sageta en le sieu ventre, e la plagua es consolidada dedintz lu, e no es mudada en las suas disposicios en re, e la femna no atrobec nocument en alcunas de las suas opperacios naturals.	And I saw a woman who had been pierced with an arrow in the belly, and consolidation had settled over her, and it had not changed in her conditions even in rest, and the woman had not suffered any other natural ailments.</end_of_turn
E vi un autre home al qual cazec sageta en la sua cara e consolidada es la plagua e romas la sageta, no atrobant aqui mota dolor, e motz semblantz ad aquestz.	And I saw another man who had been pierced with an arrow in his face, and consolidation had settled over him, and the arrow had broken, without causing any pain, and the man remained like this.
E extrayssi la sageta del home dels princeps del rey que era cazuda en le mieg loc del nas sieu e ja havia declinat a la partida dreyta un petit, e occultada era tota la sageta.	And I extracted the arrow from the prince of the king who had been pierced in the middle of his nose, and it had already declined from the other side, and the entire arrow was hidden.</end_of_turn
E yeu fu appelat a la curacio de lu aprop le cazement de la sageta entro a tres dias.	And I was called to cure him when the arrow had entered within three days.</end_of_turn
E adonc yeu atrobegui la plagua de la sageta mot streyta; e adonc yeu inquirigui aquela am tenta subtil, e no sentigui aquela; mays el la sentia puncio dejos la aurelha dreyta, e adonc speregui que aquela punccio era per la extremitat de la sageta.	Then I loosened the swelling of the arrow wound; then I asked her how she felt, and she did not feel anything; however, she still felt the pain of the arrow which had remained in her pupil, and therefore I hoped that that pain was due to the tip of the arrow.</end_of_turn
E amplastregui le loc am emplaustre en le qual es vertut atrectiva e digestiva, confizant de mi que·l loc se apostemes per que appares a mi le loc de la sageta, per que secces sobre aquela.	I applied to her the lobe in which there is an adhesive and digestive virtue, confident that the lobe would disappear because I saw the tip of the arrow there, and it would secrete about that.</end_of_turn
E no accidic en le loc accident significant que la sageta hagues conseguit aquel loc; e yeu continuegui am le emplaustre sobre lu per motz dias e no accidic accident; e consolidada es la plagua entretant, e romas le malaute de la extreccio de lu per spazi de motz dias entro que un jorn sentic la sageta dintz le sieu nas e recontec aquo a mi.	And no significant inflammation occurred at the place where the arrow had pierced; and I continued to apply the lobe to her for several days, and no inflammation occurred; and consolidation of the swelling remained, and the patient recovered from the pain of the extraction of the arrow within a few days, until one morning he felt the arrow no longer remained in his eye and he reported this to me.</end_of_turn
E adonc yeu pausegui sobre la plagua medicina acuta corrosiva per motz dias entro que foc ubert, e am la tenta yeu assagegui aquel, e atrobegui la extremitat de la sageta subtil, la qual adhereys al fust.	Then I stopped the acute corrosive medicinal poultice for several days until I had seen enough, and I saw that it was necessary to remove the tip of the arrow, which adhered to the bone.</end_of_turn
E aprop yeu ajustegui en la apersio de la plagua per aquela medicina acuta entro que apparec a mi visiblament la extremitat de la sageta, e passec a mi temps am aquo per le spazi de temps entro quatre meses.	And I adjusted the application of the poultice for that acute medicine until it became visible to me that the tip of the arrow had appeared, and I left it in place for the space of four months.</end_of_turn>
E aprop pus que la plagua foc amplificada, e foc a mi possible entrometre las forfexs en lu, e remaure aquela, e no obezic ad eyssiment, lahoras yeu no cessegui subtiliar e ingeniar sobre aquela am manieyras de engen, entro que comensegui un dia sobre aquela am manieyras de engens pendre lu am forceps descentment faytas, segon que vindra la forma de aquelas en la fi del capitol, entro que extraxi aquela; e aprop restauregui aquela plagua.	Then when the swelling had subsided, I thought it was possible to remove the forceps from her, and I did so, and did not notice any discomfort; however, I continued to cautiously explore and manipulate it in various ways for a certain period, until one day I managed to remove it using forceps as is customary in such cases.</end_of_turn
E alcus metges jutgavan que la cartillage del nas no es restaurada, e yeu restauregui aquela e la plagua es consolidada, e sanat es le malaute per sanetat entiera, e no noguec en lu en deguna causa.	And some doctors say that the cartilage of the nose is not restored; and I restored that and the swelling is consolidated, and the patient is cured of his ailment completely, and he has never suffered from it again.</end_of_turn
E yeu recomti a tu la qualitat de extraccio de alcunas sagetas per que pauses aquo regla e significacio sobre aquo que no he dit, quar las partidas de aquesta art e las difinicios de aquela no so conprehendudas am narracio ni no comprehen aquelas le libre.	I recommend to you the quality of extracting some arrows in order to stop this rule and significance about what I have not said, because the parts of this art and the definitions of this are not comprehended by the narration or are not included in it.</end_of_turn
E le artifexs savi compara am pauc sobre mot; e am aquo que es present sobre aquo que es absent; e atroba operacio novela e instrument novel deves le descendement de las causas extranhas del art quan accideysso.	And the skilled artisans compare little with us; and in what is present they omit what is absent; and they find new operations and new instruments which descend from the causes of this art when they occur.</end_of_turn
E donc yeu dic que sagetas no son fora-gitadas dels membres en les quals son ficadas sino segon dos manieyras: o per atraccio del loc en le qual intrec; o per le contrari de la autra partida.	Therefore I say that the sagittae are not outside the limb in which they are placed, but according to two methods: either by attraction of the flesh in the place where they intersect; or on the contrary side of the other half.
E aquela que es gitada per le loc don es intrada, o es sageta procedent en loc carnos, e es atirada e fora-gitada.	And that which is placed on the flesh where it enters, or is a sagitta proceeding from the flesh, is thrown and expelled outwards
E si no obezeys a eyssiment de la hora en la qual catz, lahoras cove que tu la laysses per alcus dias entro que poyresca la carn que es al enviro de lu, e sia alleujada l‘atraccio de lu e la sua egressio.	And if you do not heed this time when the cat comes, the time covers that you must leave it lying for a few days until the surrounding flesh has healed, and the attraction of it and its egress has ceased
E semblantment si es ficada en os e no obezeys a tu a eyssiment, lahoras layssa aquela per alcus dias e itera aquela am atraccio e mocio en quascun dia, e ja es fora-gitada.	Similarly, if it is placed in bones and you do not heed this time, the time leaves it lying for a few days and iterates that attraction and movement in each day, and it is expelled outwards
E si no obezeys a tu eyssiment aprop alcus dias, lahoras cove que tu perforas en le circuit de la sageta en aquel os de tota partida am taravel subtil entro que·l loc sia amplificat de la sageta, e aprop extratz aquela.	And if you do not heed this time at all for a few days, the time covers that you must perforate in the circuit of the sagitta in that bone of the whole side towards the marrow until the place is enlarged by the sagitta, and then extract that
E si la sageta es ficada en le os del cap e ja ha procezit en un dels ventres del cervel, e apparo en le malaute alcus de aquels accidentz les quals yeu e ditz, lahoras abste de la extraccio de la sageta e layssa aquela entro que·l sieu esser sia equat aprop alcus dias; quar si la sageta perve al ciphac, lahoras la mort no es a lu prolonguada.	And if the sagitta is placed in the bone of the head and has already proceeded into one of the bellies of the brain, and appears in the illness at some of those accidents which I have mentioned, the time refrains from the extraction of the sagitta and leaves it lying until either it is equal to the aforementioned days; for if the sagitta persists at the fracture, the time does not prolong its death
E si la sageta no es ficada sino en le cors del os tant solament e no passa entro al ciphac, e roman le malaute per alcus dias, e no accideys a lu denguna causa de aquels accidentz, lahoras tu engenia en la atraccio de la sageta e en la atraccio de lu.	And if the sagitta is not placed but only in the substance of the bone and does not pass beyond the fracture, and remains in the illness for a few days, and no other accident occurs with it, the time you must consider the attraction of the sagitta and of itself.
Mays si es mot ficada e no obezeys a tu a extraccio, lahoras tu aministra taravels en le circuit de la sageta ayssi cum havem recomtat, e aprop cura le loc entro que sia sanat.	Maybe if it is not placed and you do not heed this time for extraction, the time you must administer salves in the circuit of the sagitta as we have recommended, and take care of the place until it is healed.
Mays si la sageta ja es amaguada en le loc del cors, e es amaguada del sentiment, lahoras tu inquireys aquela am tenta, e si tu sentas aquela, lahoras atira aquela am alcus sturmentz les quals so convenientz a la atraccio de lu.	Maybe if the sagitta is already hidden in the place of the limb, and is hidden from the feeling, the time you must inquire about that, and if you find that, the time draws that towards the pangs that are convenient for the attraction of it.
E si no podes sobre lu per la constriccio de la plagua e per la longitut del preon, e aqui no es os ni nervi ni vena, lahoras tu fen sobre la plagua entro que sia amplificada e que sia possible extrayre la sageta.	And if you cannot do this because of the constriction of the plague and the length of the period, and here neither bone nor nerve nor vein is to be found, the time you must wait until it is amplified and the sagitta can be extracted
E si so a lu aurelhas am las quals sia tenguda, lahoras tu deliura la carn en la qual es ficada de tota partida am tot le engen que poyras far; e ingenia sobre aquo, si no podes sobre la evasio de la carn en la fractura de las aurelhas e en torssio de aquelas entro que obezesca.	And if you have other things to do which are urgent, the time you must deliberate the entire substance in which it is placed throughout, and think about it, if you cannot avoid the substance at the fracture of the heel and in torsion of those until you obey
E quan tu administras la extraccio de la sageta en quascun loc on sia, lahoras tu usa am torcio de la tua ma am forceps a totas partidas entro que fassa aquela obezir; e subtilia am deriera subtilitat que la sageta no sia trencada e que sia fayta a tu dificil atraccio de lu e de aquela extraccio.	And when you administer the extraction of the sagitta in any place, the time you must use with pliers of your hand in all parts until you have made that obey; and take care with your left hand that the sagitta is not broken and that it is effectively pulled out from that extraction.
E si no podes sobre aquela de la tua hora, lahoras tu layssa per alcus dias entro que se poyrescan las partidas que so en le circuit de lu, e aprop itera aquela quar lahoras es alleujada.	And if you cannot do this at this time, the time covers that you must leave it lying for a few days until the parts that are in the circuit of it are healed, and then repeat that until the time is relieved
Mays si a tu fa contrarietat flux de sanc, lahoras tu administra aquo que havem dit de curacio en le sieu capitol.	Maybe if you are doing the contrary of the flow of health, the time you must administer what we have said of care in the head.
E guarda la tua vertut de inscizio de vena o de nervi, o de corda, e aministra engen en tota manieyra a tu possibla de la evasio de la sageta; e fay aquo am facilitat e tranquillitat e tarditat e fermetat ayssi cum yeu e a tu recomtat.	And keep your prudence in the initiation of veins or nerves, or strings, and administer diligently in every way possible the removal of the sagitta; and make what is easy and tranquil and tardy and firm as I have said and as you have recommended
E donc que fassas contrayre la sageta per so que·l malaute sia segon la figura segon la qual foc deves le cazement de la sageta en lu, quar es mays juvatiu.	Therefore do what contradicts the sagitta so that the illness is according to the figure according to which you must take the position of the sagitta in it, for that is more beneficial.
Mays si aquo no es a tu possible, lahoras tu aministra aquo que es a tu possible per las figuras.	Maybe if this is not possible for you, the time you must administer what is possible for you according to the figures
Mays las sagetas que son fora-gitadas per le contrari del autra partida, o que ja de lu procezeys alcuna partida a las partidas de fora, o fa gilbositat la extramitat de la sageta per sentiment de la partida pus desus de la codena propdana e vezes aquela eminent; adonc tu secsa sobre aquela; e sia la seccio segon la quantitat en la qual prenguan las forceps; e aprop atira aquela, quar ela es fayta leugiera a eyssiment.	Maybe the sagittae that are expelled from the contrary side, or that already proceed from some part to the parts outside, or make the emission of the sagitta difficult by the sentiment of the part below the coccyx and sometimes that itself; then you must desist from that; and let the incision be according to the quantity in which the forceps take hold; and then pull that out, for it is beneficial to this time.
Mays si es retenguda en le os, lahoras tu tortz lama segon contrarietat entro que la sageta enprema en le os, e amplifique a si meteys, e aprop extratz aquela.	Maybe if it is retained in the bone, the time you must twist the limb according to the contrary until the sagitta presses against the bone, and expand at will, and then extract that.
E sino, layssa aquela per alcus dias, e aprop itera aquela entro qu’en yesca.	Or leave that lying for a few days, and repeat that until it is healed
E si le fust de la sageta es en aquela, lahoras tu impelleys aquela am lu.	If the tip of the arrow is there, then you must pull it out from him.
Mays si le fust es cazut e voles aministrar inpulsio, lahoras tu intromet e aquela, si es sorda, sturment concau per so que intre la concavitat de lu en la coa de la sageta e aprop impelleys aquela am lu.	If it is stubborn and you wish to give him an impulse, then you must enter in and grasp it, if it is deaf, twist it around so that between the curvature of his limb and the tip of the arrow you must pull it out.</end_of_turn>
Mays si la sageta es concava, lahoras tu impelleys aquela am sturment fort intrant en aquela, quar la sageta es alleujada per aquela.	If the arrow is curved, then you must pull it out from him strongly by entering into it, so that the arrow is relieved by that.</end_of_turn>
E si la sageta es entoxiguada, lahoras cove que tu concaves tota la carn en la qual es le vere, si es a tu possible aquo, e aprop cura aquela am aquo que si conveneys.	And if the arrow is poisoned, then you must cover all the flesh in which it is seen, if you can, and take hold of that which is convenient for you that if you pull it out it does not enter again.</end_of_turn
E si la sageta catz en le pietz, o en le ventre, o en la vesica, o en le costat, e es propinqua per so que tu tocas aquela am la tenta, e es a tu possible secsar sobre aquela, lahoras secsa sobre aquela e guarda te de inscizio de vena o de nervi, e extratz aquela, e aprop cos la plagua si indigeys, e cura aquela entro que sia sanada.	And if the arrow has entered the foot, or the belly, or the bladder, or the ribs, and is close enough to do so, then touch that part with your hand, and if it is possible to extract it without causing injury to veins or nerves, then extract it, and apply pressure to the wound if necessary, and care for that which is inside until it is healed.</end_of_turn>
Forma de forceps am las quals so atiradas las sagetas:	Form of forceps with which arrows are grasped:
Sian las extremitatz de lor cum a bec de ausel que son faytas cum serra quan prendon sobre la sageta per so que no la layssen.	Their extremities are like the beak of a sparrow, which are useful like a saw when they grasp the arrow so that it does not slip away.</end_of_turn>
E de aquelas son faytas motas specias, grans, paucas e migieras, segon la quantitat de la grandeza de la sageta e de la sieua pauqueza, e de la amplitud de la plagua, e de la constriccio de lu.	And there are various types of forceps, large, small, medium and fine, according to the quantity of the greatness of the arrow and its thinness, and the width of the wound, and the constriction of the limb.</end_of_turn
Forma de impellent concau de aquesta extremitat conquava ayssi cum pena de ausel per so que sia alleujat le intrament de la sageta en lu, e impulcio de aquela sorda:	Method of grasping with this extremity conquers like the beak of a sparrow so that the entrance of the arrow in it is relieved, and impulse of that deaf:
Forma de impellent de sorda extremitat:	Method of extracting the deaf limb.</end_of_turn
ayssi cum ray per so que sia alleujat le intrament de lu en la sageta concava e es impellida am aquel.	like a ray so that the entrance of the limb into the curved arrow is relieved and is pulled out by that.</end_of_turn
De fleubotomia de las venas.	Of flebotomy of the veins.</end_of_turn>
Las venas de fleubotomia de las quals corr costuma de fleubotomar so .xxx., de las quals so en le cap .xvi., so es doas venas pulsatils las quals so aprop las aurelhas, dic alhasisain; doas herbas que so en les dos templars apparentz; e doas venas que so en dos lacrimals de dos huels que son appeladas aspicientz; e la vena preparada en le mieg loc del front, e la vena que es en la extremitat del nas; e doas guidegi que so al col; e doas venas que so en la labia desus; e doas venas que so en la labia dejos; e — aquestas so las venas que so appeladas algelic —; e so doas venas que so dejos la lengua.	The veins from which it is customarily bled are usually those of the limb.</end_of_turn of which there are sixteen in the foot.</end_of_turn There are two pulse veins that are close to the ankles, which are called the great saphenous veins; two veins that are in the two visible temples; and two veins that are in two holes of two nails that are called the aspicient veins; and the vein prepared in the middle of the face, and the vein that is in the extremity of the nose; and two veins that are at the collarbone; and two veins that are in the lower lip; and two veins that are in the upper lip; and — these are the veins that are called the lymphatic veins —; and there are two veins that are behind the tongue.</end_of_turn
Mays las venas que so fleubotomadas en les brasses so .v.; quar de aquelas es una cephalica, e es deves le latz silvestre; e le poble appela “la vena del cap”, e sorda, e es vena migiera, e es composta de un ram de la basilica, e de autre ram de la cephalica; e nomna aquela le poble “vena de tot le cors”, e basilica es vena la qual es pausada en le latz domestic, e es nomnada “citillar”, e nompnan aquela les vulguars “vena del ventre”; e funis del bras, e es pausada sobre le focil, e es aquela en la qual es fleubotomat, e es aquela que appar sobre le poutz per apparicio manifesta; e salvatella, e es la vena que es entre lo dit auricular e·l pus petit dit, e so en lu dos ramps.	But the veins that are bled in the armpits are worth five.</end_of_turn For of those, one is the cephalic vein, which is blind; and the people call it “the head vein,” and it is deaf, and is a minor vein, and is composed of a branch of the basilica and of another branch of the cephalic; and people call that “the vein of the whole body,” and the basilica vein is stopped in the domestic lap and is called “citellar,” and the people call those vulgars “the belly vein”; and the arm vein, which is stopped over the elbow, and is that in which flebotomy is performed, and is that which appears over the elbow for the sake of its visibility; and the brachial vein, which is between the thumb and the little finger, and is in them two branches.</end_of_turn
E en le pe e la camba so tres venas; la una de aquelas es que es dejos la curvatura del denolh del latz silvestre; e la segonda es sophena, e·l loc de lu es dejos la camba del latz domestic; e la vena sciatica, e·l loc de lu es dejos la camba del latz silvestre; e en la camba son autras venas semblantz ad aquelas.	And in the foot and the thigh there are three veins; one of which is behind the curvature of the nail of the little toe; and the second is the saphenous vein, the place of which is behind the thigh of the domestic; and the sciatic vein, the place of which is behind the thigh of the little toe; and in the thigh there are other veins similar to these.</end_of_turn
Le juvament de las venas que so aprop las aurelhas es a cataris antics e emigranea e sahafati e ulceracios del cap malas antiquas.	The help of the veins that are close to the ankles is to cause ancient catarrh, emigration, swelling and ulcers of the head, bad ancient ulcers.</end_of_turn
E la qualitat de sagnar aquelas es segon que yeu recomti a tu: es que sia ras le cap del malaute, e sia freguat le cap del malaute en le occipiti en le loc de amdoas las venas am drap ample am bona fricacio; aprop strenha le malaute le sieu col am una benda entro que apparan las doas e les locs de lor so aprop las aurelhas en dos locs depremegutz del cap; e quereys aquela am le tieu dit, e si tu sentes le pols de aquelas am le dit tieu, aqui senha am tenta.	And the quality of bleeding these is as you will recommend to me: that it should be rapid from the head of the patient, and that it should be frequent from the head of the patient in the occipital region in the place where both veins are close together and wide and in good friction; to strengthen the patient should be held by the collarbone with a bandage that appears over the two holes and their places are close to the ankles in two depressed places of the head; and you should grasp that with your thumb, and if you sit on that thumb, here is the sign that it is necessary to pull out the veins.</end_of_turn
Aprop tu pren la lancea cutellar, e es aquela que es inscident, e aprop tu intromet aquel dejos la vena en la codena entro que·l fleubotomi vengua al os.	Apop tu pren la lancea cutellar, e es aquela que es inscident, e apop tu intromet aquel dejos la vena en la codena entro que·l fleubotomi vengua al os.
E aprop eleva la tua ma am la vena e la codena a las partidas desus e inscideys la vena am inscizio inscident.	When you have taken the lancet, and it is the one that is incidental, then elevate your hand with the vein and the cord to the area below and puncture the vein at the point of incidence.</end_of_turn>
E sia la longitut de la inscizio la quantitat de dos ditz ajustatz o entorn de aquo; e fay yssir del sanc atant quant voles.	And let the length of the incision be the quantity of two fingers adjusted or around that; and do it as well as you wish.</end_of_turn>
E aprop strenh am pulvils e layssa aquela entro que sia sanada.	And then strengthen the hand with powder and leave that which is within until it is healed.</end_of_turn
E ja e precedit en le comensament del libre la inscizio de aquelas e de lor la cauterizacio.	And thus has been done in the beginning of this treatment the incision of these and their cauterization.</end_of_turn
Mays de las doas venas arterias que so als templars le juvament de la fleubotomia es a emigranea antiqua e sode malvada e obtalmia assidua e cors de superfluitatz acutas effusas als huels. And the quality of phlebotomy of these is as I recommend to you: constrict the patient's body and let the two veins appear at the feeling of appearance and let it be shown that they are leaving by letting go of the hand that was holding them; and when you see that they are going well, then you will know.</end_of_turn

And elevate the cord above the vein to the area below as I have said previously, and make the phlebotomy incision beyond, and elevate the vein in its place; and puncture it as you did with the two veins before; and do it according to the amount of your need.</end_of_turn
E aprop deslia la coartacio del malaute, e pausa le tieu dit sobre la vena per una hora, e aprop pausa sobre aquela coto e pulvils e strenh aquela desus am fort constriccio, e layssa aquela entro que sia sanada. E ja es precedida la rememoracio de lor, e de aquelas la inscizio, e la atraccio en le comensament del libre.	And thus is completed the reminder of these, and of those the incision, and the attraction in the beginning of the treatment.</end_of_turn
E donc le juvament de fleubotomia de la vena del front es aprop la fleubotomia de la cephalica a las malautias antiquas de la cara e a emigranea e rogor e ulceracios fetidas.	And thus the benefit of phlebotomy of the facial vein is near the phlebotomy of the cephalic vein to the ancient diseases of the face and to emigration and dropsy and ulcerous fevers.</end_of_turn
E la qualitat de la fleubotomia de lu es segon que yeu recomti a tu; so es que·l malaute strenha le sieu col am una benda entro que apparesca la vena; e aprop pren le insturment le qual es nompnat fossori del qual aquesta es la forma de lu:	And the quality of phlebotomy of these is as I recommend to you; so that the patient grasps their body with a bandage until the vein appears; and take with you the instrument which is called fossori of which this is the form.</end_of_turn
Pausa la puncta eminent la qual es al cap del fossori sobre aquela vena e percuteys sobre lu am penche o am autre causa en la manieyra de lu, e layssa lo sanc correr segon la quantitat la qual voles; e aprop deslia la perforacio del malaute e strenh aquela entro que sia sanada.	Pause the puncture immediately which is at the head of the fossori on that vein and puncture it on the side or in any other way as you like; and let the blood run out according to the amount you wish; and then remove the perforation of the patient and strengthen that which is within until it is healed.</end_of_turn
E alcunas veguadas es uberta am fleubotomi lat, empero no cove que·l fleubotomi sia de acuta extremitat ayssi cum les autres fleubotomis, abantz sia de lada extremitat, e fleubotoma aquela segon le tranvers, quar le os es propda e fort leu trencaria en lu le fleubotomi quan es subtil.	Many doctors open the vein widely with phlebotomy, but it does not follow that all phlebotomies are of acute extremity as well as the others; because sometimes the phlebotomy is of remote extremity, and phlebotomize that according to the transversion, for which the bone is properly and strongly fixed in it when it is slight.</end_of_turn
Mays le juvament de las duas venas que so als lacrimals de dos huels per scabia del huels per rogor e sebol en les huels, e a las malautias de la cara.	More the benefit of the two veins that are among the tears of two hands for scabbing of the hands for dropsy and swelling in the limbs, and to the diseases of the face.</end_of_turn
E la qualitat de la fleubotomia es que·l malaute strenha le col sieu am una benda, e aprop fleubotoma aquelas, e tu sias stant sobre le cap de lu. E sia fayta la fleubotomia segon le transvers a longitut un pauc am fleubotomi pauc, quar en le loc no es carn; e si le fleubotomi es subtil, fort leu la extremitat de lu es trencada.	And the phlebotomy is done according to the traverse from a little distance from the phlebotomy to a little distance, for in the place there is no bone; and if the phlebotomy is slight, the limb is strongly fractured.</end_of_turn

Mays le fleubotomi de la vena del nas es conferent a febre acuta e a soda vehement, e a las malautias de la cara e emigranea e rogor que accideys en la cara, e majorment quan es antiqua.	More the phlebotomy of the vein of the nose is connected to acute fever and to violent sweat, and to the diseases of the face, emigration, and dropsy that happen in the face, and more especially when it is ancient.</end_of_turn

And the quality of phlebotomy of these is that the patient grasps their body and take hold of their nose with their left hand, and take the phlebotomy slightly long and leave that in the middle of the head of the nose according to the rule, for the vein does not appear here, and the blood begins to flow immediately.</end_of_turn

Mays le juvament de la fleubotomia de las doas guidegui a constriccio de ale e a comensament de lepra e a motas malautias e inpetige e malas ulceracios corrosivas ayssi cum herpotromeno.	The joint pain caused by cold humors infiltrates every part of the body, and when it occurs in the feet, doctors customarily call it gout.
E la qualitat de la fleubotomia de aquelas es que el malaute strenha dejos quascuna en le sieu col am liament; e estia le artifexs sobre le cap del malaute, e le malaute sia sezent sobre una sezela. The quality of the flebotomy of those is that it will cause the patient to vomit before you, strengthen the belly with a belt, and turn the patient's lips up and support two veins of which one is from the right lip and the other from the left; and the sign of the two is for the blackening of either of them, and more so when in the circuit of those two veins there are many small black veins; and then prick each one for the pricking of each.
Mays si dubitacio es dejos tu, e no sabes qual es de aquelas, lahoras tu enten a inscisio de la major de aquelas, e de la pus manifesta de aquelas. E fay le semblant de las doas venas que so en las labias desus.	And do the same with the two veins that are in the lips above
Mays costuma corr mays a inscidir las doas venas que so en la labia dejos.	It is usually better to prick the two veins that are in the lip below<end_turn>
Mays de doas venas que so dejos la lengua le juvament es aprop la fleubotomia de la cephalica a prefocacios que so en le guolayro, a la malautia de la uvula, e a malautias de la boca. The quality of flebotomizing those is that it follows the patient between their teeth before it gives up, and raises the tongue, and leave the tongue from the one side of the vein and from the other side of the vein, and the color of each one is declining towards blackness

E las tuas venas que so fleubotomadas en le coyde so en las quals corr costuma en totz les homes, e la fleubotomia de lor es fayta segon dos manieyras, o pongen am le fleubotomi mirtilat o olivar a subtilitat declinant; o secsar am fleubotomi cutellar, e apelha si alnessil, e aquesta es la forma de lu:	And the veins which are flebotomized in the groin are those which customarily run in all homes, and the flebotomy of them is useful in two ways, or by making the incision at the root of the vein or by making the incision at the ankle with a needle or by cautery, and call if needed, and this is the way to do it:
E aquest alnessil es que conveneys a seccio e de aquels so specias latz e subtils segon la amplitut de las venas e segon la strictura de aquelas.
